headline: Nvidia (NVDA) Valuation Check After Expanded Multiyear AI Infrastructure Deal With Meta Platforms

headline: Warren Buffett Generated Double The Market's Returns—Until Regulation Changed The Game
summary: Social Capital founder Chamath Palihapitiya highlighted a striking pattern in Warren Buffett‘s investment performance, revealing how regulatory changes fundamentally altered returns for even the world’s best investors. headline: US Could Soon Enter A 'Debt Spiral', Exceeding Post-World War II Debt-To-GDP Record By 2030, Watchdog Says
summary: The U.S. is approaching a critical fiscal point as its federal debt is projected to surpass historical levels, raising alarms about the country’s economic stability. What Is The CBO Saying? The U.S. federal debt is on track to surpass a significant milestone, with projections indicating a troubling fiscal future. headline: Meta Nvidia AI Deal Puts Valuation And Capex In Investor Focus
summary: Meta Platforms (NasdaqGS:META) and Nvidia announced a multiyear, multigenerational partnership to build and accelerate Meta's AI infrastructure at global scale. The agreement includes millions of Nvidia chips for Meta's hyperscale data centers and the rollout of Nvidia Confidential Computing across services such as WhatsApp. The collaboration involves deep codesign between Meta and Nvidia engineering teams to support next generation AI workloads and user facing experiences. Meta Platforms,...

headline: Airbnb’s AI Travel Pivot And Meta Hire Reshape Growth And Valuation
summary: Airbnb (NasdaqGS:ABNB) is shifting toward an AI driven travel platform, expanding trip planning tools and payments features alongside its core home rental business. The company is rolling out products such as "Reserve Now, Pay Later" globally as part of a broader push to build a more integrated trip experience. Airbnb hired Ahmad Al Dahle, formerly head of generative AI at Meta, as chief technology officer to lead its next phase of AI investment across service, search, and customer...

headline: Apple Decouples From Nasdaq as AI ‘Whack-a-Mole’ Grips Market
summary: Its correlation with the benchmark has been on the decline since May, when it reached 0.92, as Apple’s decision to mostly sit out the AI arms race has turned it into an outlier compared with many of its rivals.  A correlation of 1 means the two securities are moving in perfect unison, while a reading of -1 signals they are moving opposite each other.

content.title: Apple Decouples From Nasdaq as AI ‘Whack-a-Mole’ Grips Market
content.summary: Its correlation with the benchmark has been on the decline since May, when it reached 0.92, as Apple’s decision to mostly sit out the AI arms race has turned it into an outlier compared with many of its rivals.  A correlation of 1 means the two securities are moving in perfect unison, while a reading of -1 signals they are moving opposite each other.

headline: UBS lifts forecast for big tech bond sales this year
summary: UBS lifted its 2026 forecasts for U.S. tech investment grade bond sales on Wednesday, pointing to rising spending by ‌big tech firms, while cutting its forecast for leveraged loans on expectations that ‌AI-related disruption could curb supply. Several megacap tech companies including Meta, Amazon and Alphabet have announced big increases to their ​capital expenditure plans during the latest earnings season. After years of outsized gains, big tech stocks, meanwhile, have fallen in 2026, as investors question whether heavy AI spending will generate sufficient returns to warrant lofty valuations.

content.title: UBS lifts forecast for big tech bond sales this year
content.summary: UBS lifted its 2026 forecasts for U.S. tech investment grade bond sales on Wednesday, pointing to rising spending by ‌big tech firms, while cutting its forecast for leveraged loans on expectations that ‌AI-related disruption could curb supply. Several megacap tech companies including Meta, Amazon and Alphabet have announced big increases to their ​capital expenditure plans during the latest earnings season. After years of outsized gains, big tech stocks, meanwhile, have fallen in 2026, as investors question whether heavy AI spending will generate sufficient returns to warrant lofty valuations.

headline: Nvidia Stock Rises Following Meta Deal
summary: Meta Platforms struck a deal with Nvidia to buy tens of billions of dollars’ worth of chips and other hardware for its artificial-intelligence needs.  The social-media company plans to use millions of Nvidia's Blackwell and Rubin graphics-processing units and a “significant deployment” of Grace and Vera central-processing units to build out its data centers.  The Facebook owner had considered using Google's chips.

content.title: Nvidia Stock Rises Following Meta Deal
content.summary: Meta Platforms struck a deal with Nvidia to buy tens of billions of dollars’ worth of chips and other hardware for its artificial-intelligence needs.  The social-media company plans to use millions of Nvidia's Blackwell and Rubin graphics-processing units and a “significant deployment” of Grace and Vera central-processing units to build out its data centers.  The Facebook owner had considered using Google's chips.

headline: The Race to Build Data Centers Is Driving an 'AI Debt Boom'
summary: The data-center construction frenzy is upending expectations for U.S. corporate borrowing.  If Amazon, Meta and Google follow through on their planned investment, total spending by so-called "hyperscalers" could hit $770 billion this year, UBS said—23% higher than its previous forecast.  The bank said U.S. tech companies would continue to borrow globally, after Alphabet's recent $31.5 billion deal, which included bonds in Swiss francs and British pounds.

content.title: The Race to Build Data Centers Is Driving an 'AI Debt Boom'
content.summary: The data-center construction frenzy is upending expectations for U.S. corporate borrowing.  If Amazon, Meta and Google follow through on their planned investment, total spending by so-called "hyperscalers" could hit $770 billion this year, UBS said—23% higher than its previous forecast.  The bank said U.S. tech companies would continue to borrow globally, after Alphabet's recent $31.5 billion deal, which included bonds in Swiss francs and British pounds.
